So far we have seen how to add and subtract vectors and how to multiply a vector by a number. Now, we will learn how to multiply two vectors. There are actually two ways to multiply vectors: the dot product, where the product of two vectors is a scalar, and the cross product, where the product of two vectors is a vector. The cross product is defined for three-dimensional vectors, so we won't look at it in this class. We will focus on the dot product and its ability to help us find the angle between two vectors.

Definition and Basic Properties of Dot Product

Here is the definition of dot product:

Definition of Dot Product

If \(\overrightarrow{v}=\langle v_1, v_2\rangle\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}=\langle u_1, u_2\rangle\), then the dot product of \(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\) is \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=v_1u_1+v_2u_2\).

Let's do a quick example:

Example 1

Compute the follow dot product: \(\langle 2,3\rangle\cdot\langle -1,2\rangle.\)

Then \(\langle 2,3\rangle\cdot\langle -1,2\rangle=(2)(-1)+(3)(2)=4.\)

There are also several basic properties of the dot product that are useful:

Basic Properties of the Dot Product

Let \(\overrightarrow{v}\), \(\overrightarrow{u}\), and \(\overrightarrow{w}\) be vectors and let \(c\) be a scalar.

  • Commutative Property: \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=\overrightarrow{u}\cdot\overrightarrow{v}\)
  • Multiplication by the Zero Vector: \(\overrightarrow{0}\cdot\overrightarrow{v}=0\)
  • Distributive Property of Dot Product over Addition and Subtraction: \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot(\overrightarrow{u}\pm\overrightarrow{w})=\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}\pm\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{w}\)
  • Dot Product and Magnitude: \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{v}=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert^2\)
  • Scalar Associative Property: \(c(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u})=c\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=\overrightarrow{v}\cdot c\overrightarrow{u}\)

Angle Between Vectors Formula

We can make clever use of the Law of Cosines and a special way to draw the difference of two vectors to create a very useful formula!

Take two vectors \(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(-\overrightarrow{u}\). Also draw \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\) and notice the triangle that is formed by these three vectors in the left picture below. By drawing \(\overrightarrow{u}\) instead and shifting \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\), we can get a similar triangle containing \(\overrightarrow{v}\), \(\overrightarrow{u}\), and \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\), as in the right picture below:

This second picture gives us a new way to subtract two vectors. If we want to subtract two vectors \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\), put both of the vectors at the same starting point. Then the difference \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\) is the vector that points from the tip of \(\overrightarrow{u}\) to the tip of \(\overrightarrow{v}\).

Now, let's name \(\theta\) as the angle between \(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\).

Remember that \(\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\) is the length of vector \(\overrightarrow{v}\), \(\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\) is the length of vector \(\overrightarrow{u}\), and \(\lVert\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\) is the length of vector \(\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\). When we see that we have a triangle with these three sides and the angle \(\theta\), notice that we have exactly what we need to use the Law of Cosines!

Thus, \(\lVert\overrightarrow{v}-\overrightarrow{u}\rVert^2=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert^2+\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert^2-2\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

Now, let's use the formula for length to change some of this to components: \((v_1-u_1)^2+(v_2-u_2)^2=(v_1^2+v_2^2)+(u_1^2+u_2^2)-2\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

Squaring out the left side, we get: \(v_1^2-2v_1u_1+u_1^2+v_2^2-2v_2u_2+u_2^2=(v_1^2+v_2^2)+(u_1^2+u_2^2)-2\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

Subtracting \(v_1^2\), \(v_2^2\), \(u_1^2\), and \(u_2^2\) from both sides, we get: \(-2v_1u_1-2v_2u_2=-2\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

Dividing both sides by \(-2\), we get: \(v_1u_1+v_2u_2=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

Notice that the left hand side is just \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}\)! Thus, \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos\theta\).

...and this is our formula that relates the dot product of two vectors to the cosine of the angle between those two vectors! We can use this formula as is, or we can solve for \(\theta\):

Angle Between Two Vectors Formula

If \(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\) are vectors, then the smallest positive angle \(\theta\) between the two vectors is \[\theta=\cos^{-1}\left(\frac{\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}}{\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert}\right).\]

This formula never gives a negative solution as we often got from the Angle from One Line to Another Formula; it just gives you the size of the smaller of the two angles formed when two vectors are given the same starting point.

Parallel and Perpendicular Vectors

Now that we have this formula for the angle between vectors, we can more easily describe when two vectors are perpendicular or parallel.

When two vectors make a right angle, they are perpendicular. In that case, we know that the angle between those two vectors is \(90^\circ\). When we use that in the formula we just derived, we get the equation \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\cos 90^\circ\). But since \(\cos 90^\circ=0\), the equation reduces to just \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=0\). And conversely, when the dot product of two vectors is zero, we know that the two vectors are perpendicular. This is a useful test for finding perpendicular vectors.

Parallel vectors are a bit harder to describe. Clearly two vectors are parallel if they have the same direction. In that case, the angle between the vectors is \(0^\circ\), but if two vectors point in opposite directions, we would also say they are parallel. In that case, the angle between the vectors is \(180^\circ\). Now, \(\theta\) is \(0^\circ\) or \(180^\circ\) if and only if \(\cos\theta=\pm 1\). Referring back to our formula, we can derive that when two vectors are parallel, \(\lvert\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}\lvert=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\). We can go a bit further. What if vector \(\overrightarrow{u}\) is a nonzero scalar multiple of \(\overrightarrow{v}\)? Then we can write \(\overrightarrow{v}=k\overrightarrow{u}\), where \(k\) is a nonzero real number. As a consequence, \(\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert k\overrightarrow{v}\rVert=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert(\lvert k\rvert\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert)=\lvert k\rvert\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert=\lvert k\rvert\lvert\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{v}\rvert=\lvert\overrightarrow{v}\cdot(k\overrightarrow{v})\rvert=\lvert\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}\rvert\). Therefore, if one vector is a nonzero scalar multiple of the other, then the two vectors are parallel.

Parallel and Perpendicular Vectors

Let \(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\) be vectors.

\(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\) are perpendicular if the angle between them is \(90^\circ\), or if \(\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}=0\)

\(\overrightarrow{v}\) and \(\overrightarrow{u}\) are parallel if the angle between them is \(0^\circ\) or \(180^\circ\), or if \(\lvert\overrightarrow{v}\cdot\overrightarrow{u}\lvert=\lVert\overrightarrow{v}\rVert\lVert\overrightarrow{u}\rVert\), or if one of these vectors is a nonzero scalar multiple of the other.

    3. \(\overrightarrow{0}\cdot\overrightarrow{v}\)
